item.title: Enchanting base
item.dc:creator: @Clawz_fury lare69
item.description:
@Clawz_fury wrote:

You could make it better by making it more flexible. You are also using static-access to this when none of the fields are static. If the fields were static, it wouldn’t work.

How do I make it more flexible? And what is a static field?

How do you make this more flexible? Object orientation. You have my msn. I’ll walk you through every step.
And what is a static field? Think of a static field kind of like a global variable. For example, in your Player class you have:

But every character on your server can have a different value for starter. Why do you think this is? because starter is not static, meaning the variable is instanced for every player

but if you had

It means that there is only ONE copy of this field in existence, meaning its NOT instanced for every player. So basically, this one variable applies for every single player! Making it ‘global’ in a sense.

Why do you think the ‘players’ and ‘npcs’ arrays are static? because there is only one list of players! Why would we have a list of players for every player LOL?

A lot of people don’t know this surprisingly. It’s one of the first things you learn on the Java website here.

I’ll find the exact quote for you

The Java programming language defines the following kinds of variables:

[ul][li]Instance Variables (Non-Static Fields) Technically speaking, objects store their individual states in “non-static fields”, that is, fields declared without the static keyword. Non-static fields are also known as instance variables because their values are unique to each instance of a class (to each object, in other words); the currentSpeed of one bicycle is independent from the currentSpeed of another.[/li]
[li]Class Variables (Static Fields) A class variable is any field declared with the static modifier; this tells the compiler that there is exactly one copy of this variable in existence, regardless of how many times the class has been instantiated. A field defining the number of gears for a particular kind of bicycle could be marked as static since conceptually the same number of gears will apply to all instances. The code static int numGears = 6; would create such a static field. Additionally, the keyword final could be added to indicate that the number of gears will never change[/li][/ul]

Read full topic

If you have no clue what object orientated programming is you need to read up on some java, and look at some examples of oop in actual rsps code:

item.title: Enchanting base
item.dc:creator: @strucker Strucker
item.description:
@strucker wrote:

So i had nothing to do, and i decided to write an enchanting base for you, its all blank, you’ll have to add the powerups and link it with the packets and methods, if you’ve any suggestions please comment
Note: You will only be able to enchant one weapon, and once you die or logout you’ll lose your enchanting points, also i have one question, do you guys have any emote or gfx that i would use for enchanting?..

[code=java]
/**
*Enchanting base for weapons.
*

  • @author strucker
    */
    public class Enchanting {

    Client c;

     public Enchanting(Client c) {
 this.c = c;
 }
 
 /**
  * The enchanting level
  */
 public int level = 0;
 
 /**
  * Checks wether the weapon is enchanted or not
  */
 public boolean weaponIsEnchanted = false;
 
 /**
  *  unEnchants the weapon
  */
 public void unEnchant() {
 weaponIsEnchanted = false;      
 }
 
 /**
  * Resets enchanting level
  */
 public void resetLevel() {
 level = 0;      
 }
 
 /**
  * The method used to enchant weapons
  */     
 public void enchant(int lvl) {
         
         switch(lvl) {
                 case 1:
                         if(level => 1) {
                         weaponIsEnchanted = true;       
                         } else {
                         sM("You don't have the required level to enchant.")
                         }                               
                         break;
         }
 }
 
 /**
  *Checks if player has the required items to enchant.
  *Item 1 could be set to enchanted book, and item 2 to the weapon
  *to enchant. 
  */
 public void playerHasItemsToEnchant(int item1, int item2, int lvl) {
         if(weaponIsEnchanted = false) {
         if(playerHasItem(item1, 1) {    
         if(c.playerHasItem(item2, 1){
         enchant(lvl);   
         } else {
         sM("You have already enchanted one weapon");
         }       
         }
         }
 }

}[/code]

Now in your logout and applydead method, probably located in your client.java, add this.

Enchanting.resetLevel();
Enchanting.unEnchant();[/code]
this resets our enchanting level, and says that our weapon is no longer enchanted.

now in our packet 192 add this. (replace the #### with something you think its good for enchanting table)
[code=java]if(UsedOnObjectID == #### && itemID == 1289) {
c.Enchanting.playerHasItemsToEnchant(4155,1289,1); // rune sword
}

now in our wear boolean add this.
[if(Enchanting.weaponIsEnchanted = true { if(playerHasItem(1289, 1) { currentHealth += 5; } }
So now that our weapon is enchanted when wear it it heals us 5. i just gave an example on how it could be used.
don’t forget to make the constructor for echanting in client.
If you’re gonna post something useless please dont post.

Read full topic
